job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse Home Visiting Nurse in Barrie, ON
pros: Easy days. Great managers that care. Set your own pace.
cons: Low pay if slow ( pay per client), must do over night on call a few times a month and you get no money for it if no one calls

job_title: Personal Support Work Psw in Niagara, ON
pros: The clients were wonderful, very sweet people.
cons: Hired on full-time but not given consistent full-time hours. I would be expected to be available 8 hours a day even if I was only given 3-4 hours of work. Other days I was given 7 hours of clients who lived in 3 different cities, yet I was not paid for drive time in between clients, so it could end up being an 8.5 hour day but you're only paid for 7 hours. Oftentimes I would have multiple clients booked for the same time slot, for example 6 clients who all needed morning care. Clearly this was not possible, so some clients would be upset I couldn't make it in the morning, and cancel my visit, which would result in me not getting losing pay. It was clear the people making our schedules had little regard for what it was like for those of us on the road.

pros: Supportive team lead Thorough training Ample of resources

review_title: Not better then a $20 gift card for Christmas
job_title: Personal Support Work Psw in Ottawa, ON
pros: If you make nice with the ppl making schedules find a good mentor from the company you will advance. Great perks with other companies like discounts. I can say that they try to be as sanitary as possible and provide you with adequate supplies, masks, gloves, PPE equipment.
cons: you use your own vehicle to drive all over and outside of town, I got 7$ every 2 weeks. can't claim your car expenses on taxes, not even gas{they give you a letter with your T4 stating that} they don't optimize your schedule to save you gas or make sense. Imagine you day: drive to point M, then go to A, D,J.K, back to D, then go to V, T, Z, back to J and finish at P. but you live near B. wouldn't it make sense to go in either alphabetical or backwards and finish near home? It's my gas, my time, my vehicle. Thanks for giving the contract but at this point i am an independent contractor and should be treated as such. There's no help from HR. I've once had a "private conversation with HR" with the manager whom i had a dispute with at the time. That to me was very unprofessional and when i mentioned it, i was called into another meeting with HR about my behavior towards said manager.

review_title: You have to love what you do

review_title: Decent job but terrible treatment for part timers
pros: Working from home Ability to work night shifts or day shifts Really friendly staff members Rewarding work Good pay for the amount of work Decent training program Good technological equipment that is modern and works well
cons: Part-time employees get treated like second class citizens. If you are a part-timer, you have to work a minimum avarage of hours to get benefits (22.5 hours per week on average over a 6 month period) which gives no wiggle room for sick days. So if you want benefits, prepare to never be able to get sick and take a day off for illness or vacation or even if your parent passes away without making that day up by picking up another shift. Also, they just cut the hours of ONLY part-timers who already barely have any hours to begin with. Cutting hours is definitely better than being laid off but the cut backs should have been made for everyone not just those who are part-time. All Team Leader opportunities are full time and only during day shifts so if you're a night shift employee, forget about moving up in the company. The company is also very cheap when it comes to employee retention and satisfaction... While I appreciate any kind of reward or gift, they literally gave out $10 gift cards as a Christmas bonus... Laughable and embarrassing, especially when they take a few dollars from every single one of our pay cheques every two weeks which amount to way more than $10 and there are rarely any other events such as team building events or anything of the sort. They also came out with a new reward system that is a complete joke and feels more like an upline of a pyramid scheme than an actual reward program (to get the most out of it, you need to share job postings with people and have people you know join the company. You do get rewarded in this new program for good scores on quality assurance but not very often and not enough points to actually make any difference.

review_title: Good Company, but not enough hours.
job_title: Personal Support Worker in Niagara, ON
pros:
Competitive Pay
Benefits, if you have enough hours to qualify.
Schedule Flexibility
Nice Staff, Supervisors, and Co-workers.
cons:
I have been with Saint Elizabeth Health Care, almost 16 years, I have enjoyed working for the company, however, I would have to say that the cons are: No full-time positions, and if they do, I never get offered one. You have to be able to drive, all over Niagara, Haldimand, Brant and Norfolk Counties, if you want to have hours. You will not receive proper mileage pay, especially at the price of gas, nowadays, and how expensive it is. You have to have a certain amount of hours, to keep your benefits, so if you are not putting in enough hours, kiss your benefits good bye. They could certainly be more organized and professional, when dealing with Clts,, Customers, Staff and people in general.
No hours. I have been with this company for 16 years, and they never have any hours to give me. After, all this time, I am forced to look for other work, because this position offers little to no hours, and I cannot live, or pay my rent, bills, my daily living expenses. When you can no longer, do the job you were hired to do, they will let you go. Their is no advancement in this company, if you are a Personal Support Worker.

review_title: You have to weigh the pros and cons of what's important to you in a workplace.
job_title: Therapy Assistant in Richmond Hill, ON
pros:
Management is accommodating and fair, this is one of the reasons I've stuck around. 
Staff is great and supportive. 
EPIC documentation (Hospital) is amazing, it's all electronic 
You always have a second assistant to help you with doubles-this is huge because in other hospitals you have to see doubles with nurses and PSW's. 
Great place to start out if new, you get good learning opportunities.
More likely to get full time sooner then at other hospitals, it's a stable place to work.
Senior management does seem to listen to their staff-there has only been positive moves since I've been there.
cons:
While we just recently received a large wage increase, there is still a discrepancy with what we make vs other hospitals.
You have to work one weekend a month if full/part time (it's like this at other hospitals too)
No weekend premium-other hospitals have this
Staff turnaround

job_title: RN Visiting Nurse in Mississauga, ON
pros: BlackBerry,Autonomy where you can work along, opportunity to work with different age groups ( new born, children , elderly) and to provide care to clients in different settings ( in home, school, or long term care, schools) Opportunities to learn a variety of skills thru SEHC certifications, not confined to a building, or punching in and out, not tangled in office politics
cons: Blackberry Has no telephone capability, use your personal cell minutes,Management expects for Nurses to be accessible 27/7 via blackBerry. nCoordinators send emails all the time even when you workingBlackBerry Pay Errors GALORE, pay corrections aren't done in timely fashion and may wait 2 to 3 pay checks  to get paid, Clients have too much control,   Clients can specify visit times which gives nurses no control over their schedules,  Coordinators and supervisors aren't well trained, Wear and tear on vehicle, Pay  not competitive, lots of paper work- telephone time back and forth with Case managers, lots of faxing, Visits are unpredictable as clients can cancel without notice which means nurse loses money, not all visits are paid per hour but maybe 20 or 30 minutes duration by which a nurse will have to see more clients to make a decent check.

review_title: Great place to start - then move on
pros:
- Great learning environment for all level of nurses 
- Supportive of you to advance skills 
- Always hiring
- 24 hour assistance for anything - you're never alone 
- Very caring and skilled workers that help train others in the office, very caring supervisor 
- you will get compensated eventually if you persist pay issues etc
- compensation for additional education seems to be encouraged
cons:
- stressful if you don't have prior experience, always ask for more shifts 
- low pay
- highly unorganized within all levels
- technology never works properly 
- high turnover 
- hard to know who to call for what 
- lots of support staff are overworked and move on quickly 
- check your pay regularly, lots of mistakes 
- too many forms add to miscommunications- forms online aren't uploaded properly or are non existent making staff have to go to main office to grab paper work

pros: Great benefits and work perks
cons: Low base pay compared to nearby regions. No room for growth in current position.

pros: Good job while I was in undergrad
cons: Many times we are understaffed and it is difficult to keep up

pros: Fair salary, ok benefits, nice office, events - not enough
cons:
Salary lower than industry
Health benefits - very low for a health organization
Job description promised one thing - than you are asked to do others and the impossible and work overtime on a regular basis
There was practically no training - a manual was created as new employees learned from experience 
High expectations from the management and very stressful environment due to high volume of work
24/7 availability, including weekends and vacation also this was a 9 to 5 job M to F - and no pay or time in lieu for those extra hours. No understanding for work life balance, including sick days or vacation
Most people eat at their desks 
There are cliques in the office - lots of gossip, people seem nice, but a vast majority are fake
Lots of turnover - in that department in almost 4 years - 7 people left or they were fired - a lot of this happens due the management fight for power and wrong directives
Performance reviews are done based on unrealistic expectations for the job/ workload and time spent working (at the office or from home)
There is a lack of communication between the higher management and the employees - again lots of behind the scene politics and fight for power
Very disorganized environment - resources available - but hard to access

job_title: Personal Support Work Psw in Ajax, ON
pros:

cons:

Over scheduling when they are short

pros: SE health is Accommodating and yu gain a lot of experience
cons: The pay was not the best for an RPN

review_title: A Difficult Job in many ways
pros: The type of work being done is very important. Helping people stay in their homes and avoid being institutionalized and bringing the health care to them in their home. Providing optimal client service. It's all very important.
cons:
- Management did not know how to do the job and could not give thoughtful feedback
- Training was inadequate and not done by a qualified trainer
- Constant employee turnover and staff shortage with no change in expectations of work done by individual people - ie if your 4-person team has 3 people absent, you do the work for 4 people.
- Client contact centre and taking new referrals was too much for one job
- The pay did not reflect the amount of work done - pay too low
- In all the time working there, I never had any breaks or lunches
- Stressful conditions; clients calling with urgent medical needs, no staff to assign to them, sometimes clients needs not taken care of
- Lack of staff during evening hours to assign to clients - you can't give a nurse 15 hours in a day, that's ridiculous
- No guidance in what to do in stressful situations

pros: nothing, everything sucks about this company, low pay
cons: terrible workload. fire people unjust

pros: Management support, great culture and team
cons: Too much work and have to work extra hours

review_title: Go with another government based agency
job_title: Psw Personal Support Worker in Oshawa, ON
pros: Average benefits if the paper works done
cons: ripoff agency working under the government

pros:
-Strong leadership and support from management
-Flexible working hours
-Caring and compassionate staff- they actually care about how you feel and value your opinions
-Real team communication and support
-Valued ideas and asked for your opinions on many aspects of the job that would eventually impact you as a team player
-Fun and energetic environment
-Commitment to improving your own skills and that of the team's= always striving to be better and better at what we do
-New programs and technologies allows us to be creative and have fun at the same time
-Management is great
cons: None that I have noticed so far. Sometimes other people on the same floor are very quiet but that's because they're working and have other things to do.

job_title: Personal Support Worker in Barrie, ON
pros: You get to help individuals in the community which is rewarding being able to support clients staying in their homes with their families.
cons:
The scheduling is bad.  Sometimes I’ll have 1-4 hour gaps between clients which makes you lose money since you use your own gas and vehicle.   I was told before starting this wouldn’t be an issue however I’ve had some days where I even go and visit 1 client or sometimes 0 is on my board.  Some days your busy and some days there is just no work.

Another downside to going into peoples homes is you have no idea what your walking into.  And your main communication is through email on the company phones which can be disadvantageous when in an emergency situation.  There is also times where nobody answers your phone calls or it takes time to get through to someone.

pros: Lots of work experience and people are generally nice. It is fun once you get into the flow of the week. You get to meet tons of new people and this work will teach you a thing or two about independence and responsibility.
cons: Coworkers will not go out of their way to help you. Like any job, it may become hard at first but eventually you start to get into the flow of the day. Unfortunately, you must go through this tough time on your own and many of the others in the health care team will not be very understanding. In team meetings, it may sometimes feel like a power struggle but finding at least one other person in the team to vent with usually works.

review_title: Paid too little for the HUGE amount of work you do
job_title: Registered Practical Nurse in London, ON
pros: Flexible hours, meet very interesting people, independent, utilizes critical thinking skills.
cons: LOTS of paperwork on your own free time as they don't provide you with a tablet to complete care plans and other forms in the clients home. Annoying and time consuming to set up your next day and call all of your clients. Sometimes difficult if you don't have a supply that you need. Can be dangerous working in strangers homes, you never know what you're going to come across. Rate of pay is too low for what we do.

review_title: Exciting Workplace offering more if you want
job_title: Personal Support Worker in Trenton, ON
pros: I am a satisfied Part-Time PSW out in the field (Home Care), and I consistently feel well looked after by my Supervisor and Coordinator in particular. As well, I like I am listened to by other levels of staff in "higher" departments. If you want to move up in your career, you simply have to show your keen interest, and you will be noticed. They offer wonderful monthly Team Meetings, which are always enlightening.
cons: Sometimes communication of clients needs can be a bit on the slow side, especially if it involves the CCAC. This is not necessarily the fault of Saint Elizabeth.

job_title: Personal Support Worker in Simcoe, ON
pros: Working one on one with clients
cons:
Huge lack communication 
Low hours they say “full time”, but don’t be surprised if you only get 2-3 hours a day 
Extremely low pay even after many years of service 
Only paid mileage over 50kms in a day 
Huge gaps in scedualling, bring a blanket and pillow, you will be in your car a lot and management does not care 
They don’t check up on clients often if at all, you can report issues, call and email your supervisor and other no help at all! 
You will have no life, they say flexible but if your not “available” from 6am to 10pm everyday you will hardly see 8 hours and won’t make your bills. Zero flexibly.
They don’t stand up to their motto!

review_title: Wonderful career when  I first started but quickly turned into a job that I was starting to hate.

Casual dress code
cons: overworked in hours, no lunches, no breaks.  Unable to move up in the company.  Top heavy with management and the new/entry level employee is over looked.  No regard for employees when scheduling hours.  You can work 24 hours in a row without them acknowledging their error.  They do not support their staff.  Often put in their face the benefits of management and what they are entitled to.  Years go by without being offered permanent status, either full or part t ime.  Thus, no benefits after years of service.  Employees feel insecure in their positions, regardless of number of service.

pros: Easy to get a job and move up to a respectable position due to a high turnover rate in the office. Co-workers there are friendly and hard-working.
cons: There is limited upward mobility after the first year being there. There is always more work than can be reasonably handled which means staying late and often times working for free because claiming the hours is too much of a hassle.

review_title: Love the job but not the compensation
pros: Practice to full scope. always hours to pick up
cons: Lots of paperwork for no compensation, lots of "office politics" despite working in the community.  Change in compensation for travel and on-call shifts (results in lower pay for staff). Very hard to be off shift and relax due to constant contact from company for further information or offer of more hours

review_title: Lack of management support and variable hours
pros:
- Colleagues are a great (and only) sense of support. 
- Clients and families are appreciative of care. Sense of strong “community” collaboration. 
- Especially in emergent needs, management and coordinators are flexible and will try their best to meet your needs (from experience)
cons:
- Poor support from direct management especially in regards to advocacy for clients’ well being. Will need to reach out to upper management to defend your stance. 
- Not recommended as primary job. Hours are variable. One week you may work overtime and the next week you will be dramatically reduced. 
- Lack of professional development and growth so it’s not as easy to branch out to other opportunities if you are a younger nurse

pros: I really can't say that there are any PROs to working for this company.  I deeply regret ever working for this company
cons: The work environment is TOXIC.  Heavily biased to favourite employees that aren't even trained in the medical profession. Training was dismal and it was a swim or sink, learn as you go and get yelled at for making mistakes.  Staff were treated with such disrespect and supervisors turned a blind eye to it as long as the work was getting done.  I ended up leaving.  Too much to witness.   Not a people company and if you don't believe me just ask yourself why such a high overturn of staff??

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hamilton, ON
pros: They have a lot of employees (not sure if that's a pro)  Their address is convenient
cons: Top heavy with management not sure what they are all doing.  Chaotic and irresponsible  with correspondence.  They treat their entry level staff like outsiders, showing disrespect and inconsideration.  Barely a weeks worth of training until you work alone.  Terrible company to work for.  Unless, of course, you might be one of their 1,000 managers.

pros: Great hours Monday to fri work every other weekend
cons:
A little more then an hr drive to get PPE when you need it 
Pay is under most homecare company’s 
Not too much support form management 
Our work goes unrecognized if we didn’t do our jobs their wouldn’t be a company ...time to look out for employees

review_title: Great people, but shady corporate practices and poor upper management.
pros:
Little work drama as most people that work here are incredibly nice and supportive. 

Opportunity for learning opportunities (though generally the standard of knowledge you receive is not equivalent to trend/real world practices).

Generally a pretty good work life balance. 

Overall, company is doing work for the greater good.
cons:
Zero transparency with job expectations and pay and how to move up. You cannot see what your pay grade is thereby stunting your ability to see what you are working towards which in turn makes  the year end review is the most archaic and backwards way to evaluate performance. 

Title does not match what is expected so you will inevitably be underpaid. They will tell you title doesn't matter but it 100% does.

Management structure makes no sense in who reports to who. If you are liked, they will make up jobs for you. 

No bonuses (although managements gets bonuses).

Not for profit wages for which could be stomached if management didn't undermine your worth when it mattered.

Senior Management is unqualified. Hasty, childish and emotional decisions often made which trickle down to the staff actually doing the work. This becomes extremely discouraging.

Projects are also unnecessarily behind trend (poor/out of date management) , lack mission and bigger picture detail, and take too long to complete mostly because of internal bureaucracy. 

Finance and legal either need more staff or an overhaul to their process. Super archaic process with no intention on being updated. Absolutely makes the company look poor from a vendor standpoint which is unnecessary since the company is much smaller than most corporations. 

Success is never measured here so you never know what the goal is or what you're working towards. This was the real kicker as it feels like you're constantly creating random things with no end in sight. 

Next to no work culture with an awkward mix of "lifer" employees who just want to keep their 9-5 and young people.

job_title: Client Services Coordinator in Cambridge, ON
pros: I loved the reason for the work -- to take care of people in their own homes who needed the support of therapists from many different disciplines.
cons: Sometimes management forgets the logistics of the jobs on the front lines, and the volume of work sometimes means that the time it takes to process the referrals and reports exceeds the time available.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hamilton, ON
pros: Met some of the best people ever. Some of them got me through tough times. My personal boss always tried to be as accommodating as possible inspite of dealing with some unreasonable people and situations further from the top. Got paid on time. Can be an experience builder for a short stint for your resume.
cons: The most hideous place I have ever worked. I feel top management was engaged in too much confusion and over optimizing. People like myself were often screwed out of due compensation because of their applications of human resource laws. You will be promised a full time job when you first join but sadly, they over employ so many people that it becomes hard to get a full time shift. And when they do get you to full time, they will try to find a way to push you out by giving you abnormal hours to work which doesn't go into overtime because of how they have their work week listed. They are also highly stingy about the heat and rarely listen to people before a catastrophe is about to break out. I used to freeze to death at early morning shifts there and management was least bothered about it inspite of my repeatedly complaining about it. I couldn't even put on a personal heater because they baby proofed the power bar because they feared there would be a power outage if people did hook on. Yet when it came to their newest of technology, they would miraculously have power bars that were sufficient to accommodate those. Once the building furnace broke down in the December winter and we had to work through that cold for 5 days because of some odd part which they weren't able to get brought into the office. This made me wonder why in the era of fedex, they couldn't get the part brought in sooner instead of waiting for a human being to personally bring it in. And no exaggeration, many of us were working with blankets on us and we went through a month's supply of hot chocolate in less than 5 days when this happened because people were so ridiculously cold. And we couldn't even ask for more hot chocolate because the quota for the month was gone. And even if they are not willing to commit to it being their fault for not listening, human lives should have mattered. They are also highly deficient in communicating sudden changes in the office. Like you could get locked out of your computer because of some software adaptation that they neglect to tell you about and then you are out for 2 hours to get yourself back in. They also are not good at fostering an environment of cooperation. I felt like I was being pitted with my peers for no reason by management because of how they didn't run the organization properly. As well, we had no seniors guiding us on how to learn our jobs. it was ultimately that I would learn from falling and my peer next to me would be telling me how to get through my job.

review_title: Good place to work with friendly colleagues.
pros: Flexible work environment and people are friendly and helpful. Able to work independently and acquire excellent clinical nursing skills. Good clinical supports in place.
cons: Changes take a long time to happen. Need to increase salary compared to other community nursing agencies. Not paid hourly but by the number of clients seen. Work longer than you are paid.

review_title: I was cut back in hours by 8 to 1 k   after a year
pros: clients are good except a few who do not like you
cons: communication lacking between coordinator and front line workers. Hard to get hold of supervisor as they are busy too.Made to feel bad for caring too much.

pros: Large company with a good reputation, therefore they have lots of work and are expanding. Offer good benefit package, employee pays part, and pension plan.
cons: There is  lots of pressure  put on the front line staff of PSWs. Ironic that we are caring for the health of our patients and the Psychosocial environment for the workers leaves a lot to be desired.

job_title: Personal Support Worker in South Huron, ON
pros: Flexible , supportive, caring employer that definitely tries to work with you as much as possible.  This company has my loyalty 100% because, in the area I work in anyway, you will not find a nicer boss to work for.  There are demands and stresses with any job but here they listen, try to help correct any issues, and this is the best company I have ever worked with!
cons: There is a fair bit of driving and some split shifts

review_title: Stay far away if you can!
pros:
Lots of presents to keep your mouth shut (umbrellas, bags, etc).  HR management are the worst "professional staff" I have had the misfortune to work with.  Two faced in every sense of the word.  

Other pro is they do try to offer some training.
cons: Fake people everywhere, HR Management is a true nightmare, unreasonable job expectations for senior management, poor work life balance, poor compensation.  The expectation for management is to work every day past normal business hours on a regular basis.

job_title: RN Wound Care Consultant in Markham, ON
pros: a few good supervisors but they leave
cons: dead weight supervisors who just take up space

job_title: Community Health Worker in Vancouver, BC
pros: Saint Elizabeth treats their workers like gold. The Vancouver office is very supportive and has a great team to help its Community Health Workers do their jobs properly.
cons: Some of the clients are very difficult. As well, a BlackBerry is normally used to communicate with the workers; however, I personally have worked for Saint Elizabeth for 8 months, and have yet to receive a BlackBerry.

pros: -love the people I work with
cons:
-office politics
-HSS's/PSS's are not helpful, try to avoid doing work
-no support from management team
-training new staff is terrible
-absolutely no extra hours, resulting in no real coverage on days off or sick days
-under paid and over worked
-no bonus, no merit increase, I've worked there for 3 years and I get paid the same as a CSR who started today.

review_title: Not a hopeful or happy employer
pros:
Work from home; some
People I worked with make it worthwhile to work there—-you have to find those folks who will have your back. Always doing new things in healthcare
cons: Poor pay; micromanagement; Lack of support; People are not kind to each other; people shame others when mistakes happen; people get away with a lot of inappropriate behaviours and I don’t understand why change doesn’t happen to move people out; a company I think puts up with aggressive people because it’s the culture that has been created. It makes no sense.

pros: There are really no pros to having worked for this company, except to say that receiving a regular paycheck payed the bills.
cons: There are a lot of cons....bullying, over worked, under staffed, a lot of work for extremely minimal pay, very demanding job, toxic work environment.

review_title: Visiting nursing involved driving around in the community to homes, schools, clinics etc to deliver health care.
pros:
It is an incredible honor to be welcomed into the homes and personal lives to deliver health care. You really do become part of the family and you really do make a difference in the lives of others. 

Community nursing is a great place to learn new skills. You get a broad range of clients from all walks of life, ages, diseases and needs.
cons:
The way this organization is run places so many barriers for nurses to do a good job. There is so much bureaucracy involved in providing care which creates so much extra work for nurses. There is a huge lack of communication between nurses and the offices. The amount of time involved with documenting takes away from the nursing as well. There is a hostile blame culture at Saint Elizabeth. Management is unsupportive. As a nurse, I want to enrich lives and empower the patients I cross paths with. However, it's hard to be a good nurse when you don't feel supported and are made to feel mediocre by upper management. 

Training and orientation is unorganized and not motivating, especially for new nurses. Although Saint Elizabeth provides a clinical practice resource team hotline 24/7, it is simply not enough when more clinical support is needed. Often times I have found myself scheduled to see a complex client that needs a specific nursing task done that I have not been trained for but was scheduled to see that client anyway. 

I found that when I had questions that needed answering, the upper management often pass the buck to another employee. Individual workers are expected to seek out their own training. 

For example; if you wanted to get extra help learning how to work around a port a cath, you are expected to find a co worker to do a joint visit so you can (hopefully) learn in one visit. However, there are instances when the coordinators will schedule you to a client that you are not trained to care for, which is dangerous for both you and the client. Better training and clinical support is needed. Management should be more proactive with providing training as well.

review_title: Disorganized top-down management with no accountability
pros: There really are no pros when working at Saint Elizabeth. There are no accommodations of note. The building does not have a cafeteria and only ONE dedicated free space (fits 15-20 people) for people to enjoy. Many people are forced to eat at their desk or to leave the building altogether. There is no gym or any immediately-walkable locations to visit for take-out food/drink.
cons:
Lack of Accountability from Management: 
Managers will constantly deflect blame and are quick to point fingers instead of owning mistakes and working to correct them. Eventually, those mistakes fall into the ether while managers argue over who is to blame. The lack of accountability stretches far beyond management and impacts every aspect of the services provided and the company as a whole. Nearly every person that works at Saint Elizabeth is looking out for themselves.

Lack of Reviews and Direction: 
Management does not properly conduct formal employee performance reviews. You will never know how your performance is being perceived and how to improve yourself. Directors and Management offer vague directives and hold unrealistic expectations. You may attempt to clarify the instructions, but will be met with frustration. Many employees feel unprepared and feel that they lack the necessary support to succeed.

Poor Culture: 
The people that work at Saint Elizabeth are very passive-aggressive. The culture itself is also highly toxic. Of course, there are many nice people to work with, but across the board, many people feel drained and discouraged by the company and its mismanagement.

Lack of Growth and Opportunities:
While Saint Elizabeth touts itself as a steadily-growing company, there are very few opportunities for upward mobility. Many managers also prefer to hire externally rather than promoting from within their own teams. Bottom line: If you perform well, you will be kept in your role (and strung along with passing compliments or promises of opportunities) with little chance for a raise or promotion. There is a high employee turnover here.

Lack of Diversity:
There is a great lack of diversity within the company, especially amongst management and executives. Healthcare is a highly-diverse field, especially in Canada. How is it that a healthcare company features and hires so few visible minorities?

Middling Benefits and Compensation:
The benefits package offered is middling, at best. Good luck claiming expenses as well - management will put up a fight prior to allowing an expense for an off-site drive or meeting. Need to take the 407 to get to Hamilton when a last-minute meeting comes up? Need to pay for parking at a downtown B2B meeting? The offered salaries are below average (to be expected of a not-for-profit), but they certainly do not match the efforts of the employees.

pros: What I enjoyed most about working at Saint Elizabeth was the recognition that you received for a job well done.
cons: The downside to working at Saint Elizabeth is the requirement of working weekends, holidays and evenings. In addition, the opportunity for a promotion was very slim.

review_title: good place to start your nursing career
job_title: Registered Nurse in North York, ON
pros: paid education,  subsidized RNAO membership, benefits, pension plan, ability to pick up clients and work in different programs
cons: low pay, hours are not guaranteed.

pros: Flexibility on making your own schedule.
cons:
Low pay/ salary.
Community work involves a lot of driving , with very low paid mileage, no pay for time spent with driving.
Benefits package is minimal. 
No pay for everyday, office work ( i .e - booking , cancellation calls, files), also no money allocated for office expenses.

review_title: Good for Gaining Experience...Don't Stay Long
job_title: Personal Support Staff in Ottawa, ON
pros: It's a good way to earn experience if you are new in nursing or personal support. The work is very rewarding, and you learn all sorts of skills. Christmas time is nice, as lots of the clients give you little gifts.
cons:
The pay, the compensation, and how the office staff treats the front-line workers. We are always referred to ask "workers", and my schedule is constantly being changed overnight, so I wake up in the morning to find 3 new clients added without any notice, which forces me to run late all day, and the clients are angry with me. When I speak to the office about it, I either get no reply, or they tell me it's just  the way it is. Huge chunks of my paycheques are often missing, and I have to chase them for months to fix it. The turnaround is awful in the office - so you never really feel backed up by anyone - especially since you'll probably won't even meet your supervisor in person before they quit. The lack of support is a huge issue. I was being abused by a client and their family for months, and the office told me to go and never did anything about it even though it was being reported on a daily basis. 
They do not accommodate to workers with disabilities whatsoever. They focus on hiring new employees and don't take care of the ones they currently have.
Clients are often felt feeling frustrated by lack of communication from the office and lack of consistency in their visits.
There are always parties for the office staff, but only one a year for the front-line staff, and we have to pay for it. 
The benefits are very expensive and not very good. 
There is zero accountability from the office and management when they are in the wrong with clients - they are quick to blame front-line workers for everything.
Nobody greets you when you go in the office.

review_title: It’s important to me to write a positive feedback with this company since I feel comfortable as working with them
job_title: Personal Support Staff in Chattanooga, TN
pros: I enjoyed working with SE health care because the offered me comfortable schedules and reasonable paying , I really appreciate this company and all the staffs worked over there
cons: To be precisely i dont have any negative reviews with SE health care

pros: Clients and Co -workers. Medical benefits and pension plan.
cons: Workers put in unsafe working conditions, little respect from superiors or upper management. Upper management does not want or consider any input from employees. You are just a number no loyalty to long term employees as new employees can be hired for less money. Constant staff turnover. Top heavy with upper management. No advancement what so ever for PSWs who make up 50 percent of your workforce. Years of service mean very little to this company. HR is negative and extremely uncooperative, very little help from current HR team. If managers need time off or accommodation they are treated much better than front line staff. Supervisors have no problem getting vacation and time off. Does not work like that for front line staff. This company is all about the money and making it off the backs of front line staff which is strange given it’s a non profit company. Favouritism runs rampart in this company. Preferential treatment for Management and for friends and family.

pros: You will always be busy at St Eliz. You are not limited to your role. Can learn and help with other desks. Helping to  ensure our clients get the care they need. Fun environment but expected to get work done and wear headset. Lots of calls from clients and families.
cons: Pay could be better for the volume of work.

pros:
Fair wage
Fair benefits
Nice people to work with
cons:
Upper management fails to plan long-term strategies or goals.
Corporate restructuring has resulted in undefined roles or job descriptions for management.
Complete lack of communication regarding corporate issues or changes.
Poor job training.

pros: Low pressure. Very friendly people. Understanding of family constraints with work hours. Care deeply about their clients and the work they do.
